The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some debate. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is a significant advance over previous attempts to provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To gain insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the transcriptome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the origin of parasitic lifestyles and the evolution of the parasite genome. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a potential target for the development of antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some proton channel residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of a growing population. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially as the Earth warms, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. This will have important implications for global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. The results also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammal species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from mean sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Grass RRA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of size-matched grazers—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, and many are not prepared to weather the crisis. Finally, many businesses are not confident that they will be able to access the government’s new lending programs.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem, but its magnitude and the nature of its impacts are still debated. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly because of size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The age of the solar system is a key parameter for the understanding of the formation of the solar system. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. These grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides a new perspective on the origin of the solar system. It also provides a new perspective on the origin of the oldest material

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of life. In humans, this ability is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. In other species, this limit is imposed by resource availability. Here, we show that the ability to reproduce is also limited by the mother’s metabolic power in a variety of placental mammals. We show that the increase in reproductive output associated with domestication and allonursing is due to an increase in metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability. This result suggests that the metabolic power of the mother is the primary factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a high mortality rate. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor prodrug VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in proteolipid protein α-syn (PLP-SYN) mice, a transgenic mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other in a network. The network is responsible for integrating the multitude of signals that the endothelium receives from the outside world. The network is also responsible for coordinating the responses of the endothelium to these signals. This paper describes the nature of the network and its properties. The network is found to be highly efficient in the transmission of signals. The network is also found to be highly dynamic in its response to changes in the environment. These findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for understanding the impact of public health interventions, and for research.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for the microbiome to produce natural products is largely unknown. Here, we report the discovery of natural products produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gut of herbivores. These fungi are a previously uncharacterized group of gut microbes that have been overlooked in the search for natural products. Our results suggest that anaerobic fungi are a promising source of natural products.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness of high-anxious individuals is associated with the pharmacological prevention of subordinate status in a dyadic contest. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in the development of social dominance. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in mechanical engineering. The use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors, some of which are unachievable by a single material. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other mammals. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of evolution. The hemoglobin system is a complex of four globin proteins, two alpha and two beta, that are encoded by two genes, alpha and beta, and that are expressed in two forms, fetal hemoglobin and adult hemoglobin. The hemoglobin system is also a complex of two regulatory proteins, the alpha-globin gene enhancer BCL11A and the beta-globin gene enhancer IRF8. The hemoglobin system is also a complex of two regulatory miRNAs, let-7 and insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1). Here we show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and that it mediates the developmental silencing of adult hemoglobin in the erythroid lineage. This work suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy and succumb to the disease. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the mechanisms of resistance to therapy are diverse. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to therapy in cancer cells that is mediated by a mutation in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. This mutation protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is induced by iron and reactive oxygen species. We also identified a mechanism of ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells that is mediated by a mutation in the SREBP1/SCD1 pathway. This mutation protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptosis. We show that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that this combination therapy results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway and ferroptosis may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ channel (SOCC) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is mediated by the N terminus of the channel. This activation promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that the use of LCCBs should be carefully considered in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. This is because the levels of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM and the Ca2+ channel ORAI are elevated in these patients. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but not older-forest–associated species. The NWFP has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, and the policy has failed to meet its goal of halting the loss of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of these devices in the hours before bedtime has a significant impact on sleep. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce the amount of sleep. These effects are likely to have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas impact event is a well-known episode in Earth history, but the cause of this event is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We report the results of osmium isotope analyses of magnetic grains and bulk sediment from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio. The osmium isotope data indicate that the magnetic grains and bulk sediment are of terrestrial origin. In addition, we report the results of a study of spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania. The spherules are rare in number and size, but they are unique in that they are 2- to 5-mm in diameter and contain minerals such as suessite, which form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The presence of these unique objects at the YDB site supports the impact hypothesis of the YDB. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, which was not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both central and peripheral tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results have implications for our understanding of the evolution of plant-feeding insects and the origin of the plant kingdom.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with decreased risk. APOE is also highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain, which may contribute to the increased risk for AD. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic synapse pruning. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with increased risk for AD, at least in part, because of defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is testable in animal models. It also suggests that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is about 1,700 km in diameter and 1,500 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide insights into the formation of the Earth and its core. They also provide a new perspective on the origin of other dense solids.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for natural language processing also predict nearly all of the explainable variance in the brain responses to sentences in human participants. Moreover, the models that best predict individual differences in language comprehension also predict their performance on a language comprehension task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain mechanisms of language comprehension. They also suggest that we may be able to understand the brain in terms of its ability to process predictive information.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the problems are often ill-conditioned and the data are scarce. In this paper, we show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental difference between deep learning and scientific computing, and it has important implications for the future of scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past pandemics. This article argues that the failure to learn from past pandemics is in part due to a failure to learn from past psychological experiments. The classic experiment on the “line drawing” task is cited as a prime example of a flawed experiment that nevertheless led to a widely accepted conclusion. The article discusses the experiment’s critical design flaws and how they led to the wrong conclusion. It concludes with a call to critically assess the role of classic experiments in the field of psychology.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for the two major forms of the disease, namely, lepromatous and lepromatous-like leprosy. The two species are very similar, but the former is more closely related to the ancient common ancestor of the two species, whereas the latter is more closely related to the present-day common ancestor. This study provides insights into the evolution of these two species. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of quantum physics. It is also of great practical importance, as it determines the evolution of the information content of a physical system. In this work, we provide a complete solution to this problem for a paradigmatic model, the Heisenberg chain. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. They are exact and valid in the limit of large system sizes. We check our results against the known asymptotic behavior of the entanglement entropy in the steady state. Our findings provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths and has severely affected the global economy. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vector technology, which have limitations. Here, we describe a live attenuated vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on recoding the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro and grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the vaccine candidate is highly attenuated and generates high levels of spike-specific antibodies in hamsters. The vaccine candidate is protective at a single intranasal dose in a relevant hamster model. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Thus, COVI-VAC is a promising vaccine candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. Copyright © 2021. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model fitting, as well as the value of using a large number of outbreaks to obtain robust parameter estimates. This work also highlights the potential of mathematical models to provide insights into the history of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is a more appropriate measure of brain size, has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is not only different from that of brain size but also has a unique pattern of evolution.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-directed therapies in cancer. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal filament in all cells. They are dynamic, and their structure and function are regulated by a variety of proteins. One of these proteins is cofilin, which is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. Cofilin is also involved in the formation of stress fibers and lamellipodia, and it is a key regulator of cell motility. Here, we show that cofilin is also involved in the disassembly of actin filaments under physiological conditions, such as in a microfluidic channel. We show that cofilin binds to the actin filaments, and that this binding is enhanced by the curvature of the filament. We also show that the binding of cofilin to the filaments is enhanced by the tension in the channel. These observations are important for understanding the role of cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many beverages and foods, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may be a more effective trigger of overeating than previously thought. The findings have implications for the design of public health policies aimed at reducing the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic diversity, with a strong influence of geography on the distribution of African and Asian ancestry. This study shows that Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history.

We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences that person’s own emotional state. This work suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, and that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others, and that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have profound effects on RNA structure and function. In this study, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can alter the bacterial translation system and human cells. We find that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA codons and that this can have a small but measurable impact on translation. This study highlights the potential for mRNA modifications to influence the translation of endogenous mRNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. Longitudinally, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. They also highlight the importance of the subjective experience of worthwhile activities in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life course. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the rise of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size in four of the five extant lineages of mammals that have invaded the water. The aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body size by constraining the size of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen’s ability to attach to surfaces, which is a critical step in its pathogenesis. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is mechanochemical, as it requires the mechanical activity of the pili to induce conformational changes in the chemosensory protein PilJ, which in turn activates the pili. This system is important for the pathogen’s ability to cause disease. Our findings thus provide insight into how bacteria use pili for sensing and motility. They also suggest that type IV pili may be a target for the development of new antibiotics.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of these chemicals on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a more integrated approach to study the virus and its transmission. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of large dams in the developing world and the problems that they cause. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of amyloid plaques. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the inflammatory response in AD is not well understood. Here, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in AD. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of cytokines, which are known to be potent activators of microglia, the principal immune cells in the brain. Moreover, we show that the extent of neuron-derived inflammation correlates with the extent of microglial activation and the presence of Aβ-induced neurotoxicity. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response in AD. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of AD and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two distinct steps. The first step is a fast compaction into a polyglobular state, which is followed by a slower formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway and is the site of three destabilizing mutations. The intermediate is also the site of two of the three steps in the folding of the native protein. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, which is inactivated by stress. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is not known to decape Np4, becomes the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme. This enzyme prefers Np4-capped 5′ ends over their capped counterparts, and it generates a one-nucleotide-long RNA product as the primary product of decapping. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore the immune system during sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, sandpiles, and fire outbreaks, where systems with no external control can maintain a critical state. SOC is a very recent discovery, and its mathematical description is still in its infancy. In this paper, we describe a mathematical model of SOC, which is a continuous model, in contrast to all known models. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned continuously. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of land plants is a topic of great interest. The role of the immune system in this process is also of great interest. The immune system of land plants is similar to that of animals, but there are also many differences. In this study, we show that a group of nodule-specific peptides with conserved cysteine signature (NCR peptides) are highly diverse in sequence and exhibit antifungal activity in vitro and in vivo. The antifungal activity of NCR peptides is mediated by binding to bioactive phosphoinositides and by inducing cell death in fungal germlings. This work provides insight into the evolution of the immune system of land plants. It also provides a basis for the development of a new class of plant fungicides. This work is important for the understanding of the evolution of the immune system of land plants and for the development of new classes of plant fungicides.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common disorder of hemostasis. The mechanism also explains the effects of mutations in VWF. The mechanism is also relevant to other systems in which conformational regulation is important.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been largely ignored. This study is the first to provide a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, and to use it to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. These observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the planet is a key factor in the origin and diversification of life. However, the temperature of the early Earth was not well constrained until recently. This study provides a new perspective on the temperature history of the early Earth by using the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to infer ancient surface temperatures. The results suggest that Earth’s surface cooled from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to ∼15 °C today. This finding is consistent with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. The results also suggest that the evolution of life and environment are codependent. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the gates of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to regulate ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channel C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the regulation of K+ channel gating and inactivation. They also suggest that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help to understand the pathophysiology of K+ channel dysfunction in cardiac arrhythmia and other diseases. Malaria is a major cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. One of the key steps in the parasite life cycle is invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), which is a critical event in the pathogenesis of the disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this binding alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility of developing new strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

We also show that diamond can be demetallized by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of dry air-induced disease pathology and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. The brain is thought to process language in a hierarchical fashion, with the most complex syntactic structures unfolding in the mind’s eye. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this view is limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies a merge operation to the incoming language stream. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is a fundamental property of language processing that may be important for understanding the evolution of human language.

It is a scaffold that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We have identified a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. LH stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the ventral tegmental area (VTA), substantia nigra, or peri-locus coeruleus (LC) neurons. However, lesions of LH neurons or LC GABA neurons do not block eating. Thus, the LH circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. This circuit may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is a major factor determining crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil would allow for the delivery of nitrogen to the plant only when the plant is in contact with the bacteria, thus avoiding the delivery of nitrogen to unwanted plants. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and we have demonstrated that the bacteria can be controlled in situ in the root system of a host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a significant step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen-fertilizer strategy for agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is still losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to improve the effectiveness of remote-sensed alerts and to provide incentives for communities to detect and respond to deforestation in time to prevent it. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have unintended consequences. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an ear that is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its proteinaceous, self-manufactured web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to be a major public health concern. Vaccine development is a critical component of the response, and the development of vaccines based on recombinant proteins is a well-established approach. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein that can be expressed in large quantities, with high yield and high-affinity binding to the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. This protein can be used to generate a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine, which can be produced at high yield and is well-suited for large-volume, low-cost manufacturing. The engineered protein can also be used to generate antibodies that bind to the RBD of the variants of concern. This engineered protein can be used to develop vaccines that can be used to contain the COVID-19 pandemic.

The role of ALK in the development of human tissues is well established. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK/LTK are activated by zebrafish and human ALKALs. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings are important for understanding the role of ALK in human development and for the development of ALK inhibitors in cancer therapy.

The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is a well-documented event in history, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. We find that the plague lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the Bronze Age was not significantly different from the one that preceded it, and that the plague lineage spread rapidly across Eurasia. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. Together, these data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting database, SpillOver, is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of colorful nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of the evolution of colorful nectar.

The genetic history of Europe during the last millennium is poorly understood. This is due to the lack of genome data from the period. Here we present genome data from a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 480 and 680 AD. The analysis of their collective genetic ancestry indicates that they had a genetic origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. The rapid detection of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for early detection of emerging pathogens and for the deployment of rapid public health response. We used a cloud-based metagenomic platform to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in Cambodia. Our findings highlight the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This will enable the rapid deployment of public health response and the development of appropriate public health interventions. This study is a proof of concept for the use of metagenomics in resource-scarce settings. This will be critical for the detection of emerging pathogens in the future.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, in vitro evolution was used to improve dramatically the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme by selecting variants that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The ability to control copper levels is therefore an important aspect of life. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We also show that xan BGC-derived isocyanides are secreted and bind copper as visualized by a chrome azurol S (CAS) assay, and that inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry analysis of intracellular copper pools demonstrated a role for xan cluster metabolites in the accumulation of copper. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also provides a mechanism for the antimicrobial properties of xanthocillin and other isocyanide-derived metabolites. This work suggests that the xan BGC is a potential target for the development of antifungal agents. (Read more)

The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature, low-pressure polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost events and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the leaf-out strategies of trees. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are not fixed, but can be modified by natural selection. Our results have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is unclear. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients of Th17 transfer, indicating that they require the development of Th1-like cells to induce disease. Th17 cells also supported the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells induce colitis may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and by toxic effects of misfolded proteins. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to test potential therapies. This method will enable the study of the disease in large numbers and will be useful for the development of new therapies.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates A. phagocytophilum transmission. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may have implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The origin of the avian flight apparatus is a major evolutionary transition in the history of birds. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the Pygostylia and adds important information about the origin of the avian flight apparatus.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. The ability to change color is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times in anurans (frogs and toads), and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin, the main pigment in the blood of vertebrates. This discovery provides a molecular basis for the evolution of color change in anurans and other vertebrates. It also provides a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) on messenger RNA (mRNA), and that ALKBH5 expression is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the maintenance of cancer stem cells in hypoxic tumors. (Show more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing mystery. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, in the production of parchment. Instead, we found that the use of more than one species of animal in a single manuscript is consistent with the local availability of hides. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery interval at Meishan, China, based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the retinoic acid-related orphan receptor (ROR) family, which is involved in various biological processes, such as cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease.
