The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune system and of vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and facilitate the fusion process.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of atoms are two of the most important properties of atoms, and they are the basis of the chemical potential of atoms. We calculate the chemical hardness and electronegativity of atoms as a function of pressure, and we find that they decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a fundamental contribution to chemistry.

Fire is a key component of many ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is uncertain. We show that changes in fire activity have acted to warm climate throughout most of the 20th century. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems.

The gut microbiota is a major component of the immune system of many animals. In this study, we show that the symbiotic bacteria of the squid Euprymna scolopes regulate their own population size in a circadian manner. We also show that the bacteria are able to metabolize a specific glycan, chitin, which is released by the host immune cells in a circadian manner. This glycan is required for the bacteria to maintain a normal population size, and the bacteria are able to metabolize it only when the host immune cells are active. This study suggests that the host and the bacteria are in a mutualistic relationship, and that the host is able to regulate the bacteria’s population size in a circadian manner. This is the first study to show that the host and the bacteria are in a mutualistic relationship. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which have led to the development of a new type of vector space model. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe from Asia, where it had been circulating for centuries. However, this assumption is based on a single hypothesis, which has not been tested. We show that the introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe was preceded by repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe was not a singular event, but rather the result of a series of introductions, each of which was delayed by 15 y. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play an important role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major prey for sea stars, which are a major predator in the marine ecosystem. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event, which is associated with a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a mass mortality event in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of blood cancer, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies for AML, ideally targeting the disease at its stem cell origin. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibody-mediated therapy for the treatment of AML

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south. We found that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of the island. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. This study will be useful for the study of the Indian Ocean and the history of Madagascar.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules, including vaccines. Our results highlight the importance of the immune system in the evolution of SARS-CoV-2 and the need for continued monitoring of the virus. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data is often not used in agricultural decision-making because it is not easily accessible, and because it is perceived as subjective and not quantitative. We show that the US Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is conducted by a large number of crop experts, can be transformed into a quantitative variable that is robust across crops, has nation-wide validity, and can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that this index is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This index can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration does not increase in response to warming in most biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with warming. These results highlight the importance of regional differences in soil respiration responses to climate change, with colder regions being considerably more responsive to warming than warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for more studies that measure soil respiration in a range of biomes, and that include measurements of soil moisture and temperature. These data are critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of plastids and their subsequent evolution are key questions in the origin of life. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of this story, as they are the only organelles that have retained their original function. We present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes under progressively relaxed functional constraints during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. Our model is based on a large dataset of plastid genomes from diverse lineages. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings provide insights into the molecular evolution of plastid genomes and their role in the origin of life. View Full-Text

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is assessed using a high-resolution large ensemble. The results show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of the regional scale in the assessment of the impact of anthropogenic climate change on drought risk. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the seconds after the explosion, is a unique record of the conditions under which quasicrystals form.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The two enzymes that catalyze this reaction are related to each other, but their evolution is not understood. Here we show that the two enzymes are related to each other, and that they are part of a larger group of enzymes that are involved in the formation of isocycles.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/AKT. However, the role of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (ASK1) in neuroinflammation is unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation in EAE. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages, but not in astrocytes, ameliorated the early and later stages of EAE. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages was required for the generation and maintenance of EAE. ASK1-deficient microglia/macrophages produced proinflammatory cytokines, which activated astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation in EAE. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occur when conditions are warm are more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad spectrum of symptoms. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It finds that this is indeed the case, and that the magnitude of this negativity bias varies considerably across individuals. The results help to explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy in patients with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insight into the mechanisms of spreading and the potential for therapeutic intervention in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. By selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection, MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a promising metabolic target, as it is up-regulated in cancer, and its activity is required for cancer cell growth. Here we identify small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This work provides a foundation for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. It also provides a rationale for the use of glycine-rich diets in cancer prevention. This work is a step toward the development of a dietary strategy for cancer prevention.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord suggests that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The Cretaceous is a key time in the history of life, with the origin of many major groups of organisms. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of plants, with the appearance of the first land plants. However, the origin of the first flowering plants, which are the most successful flowering plants today, is poorly understood. Here, we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous flowering plant that lived below the surface of the water. Montsechia is an important plant for understanding the origin of flowering plants because it is an early member of the Ceratophyllum clade, which is sister to all other flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology. However, the evolution of viruses is difficult to study, as they are typically very small and difficult to isolate. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which were isolated from human remains. We find that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the origin of the most recent common ancestor of all B19V to ∼12.6 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is significantly higher than the rate of rise implied by the IPCC AR5 models, which is 0.13 ± 0.09 mm/y2. The paper also provides a new estimate of the rate of acceleration of sea level rise, which is 0.022 ± 0.011 mm/y3. This is significantly higher than the rate of acceleration implied by the IPCC AR5 models, which is 0.012 ± 0.009 mm/y2. The paper also provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise for the 21st century, which is 2.08 ± 0.66 cm/y. This is significantly higher than the rate of sea level rise implied by the IPCC AR5 models, which is 1.39 ± 0.30 cm/y.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate in tryptophan synthase. This intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. From this analysis, a detailed three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity emerges, highlighting the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction mechanism of an enzyme. This approach offers a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotic coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued research on the development of antiviral treatments for MERS and other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. The gut microbiota is a major component of the immune system of many animals. In this study, we show that the host squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its gut microbiota through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is a major component of the exoskeleton of arthropods, including the host’s symbiotic bacteria. We show that the host provides chitin to the symbiotic bacteria only at night, when the bacteria are most active. This regulation of the host’s gut microbiota is likely to be a general feature of animal–microbe interactions.

The suspension of students from school is a common and controversial practice. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn bolsters the quality of teacher–student relationships and reduces the suspension of students. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the replication and transcription of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how MERS-CoV infects human cells, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked the sequential proteolysis required for virus entry. We found that the first proteolysis, which occurs during virus secretion, is critical for MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not of other cell types. This finding suggests that MERS-CoV has evolved to infect human cells, and may be more virulent in humans.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of global disease burden. The food choices people make are a key part of the solution. In this work, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40% and decrease meat sales by 15%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple intervention: doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available. Our results suggest that this approach could be used to make a significant contribution to the global effort to reduce environmental degradation and disease burden. This approach could be used in a wide range of settings, from cafeterias to hospitals to schools.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic environment that is constantly being remodeled by the cell to engage the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences. This is an important finding for election administration experts and policymakers. It also has implications for the broader literature on the effects of mail voting. Our results suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail are likely to be similar to those of mail voting. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the brain, and it is known to induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic increase in the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1, which triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema in hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. The scientific method is based on the idea of “selective inference”: We start with a hypothesis, and then we test it against the data. This is a very powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a number of recent developments in selective inference that are relevant in the era of big data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a key factor for the direct conversion of fibroblasts into ECs. ETV2 is essential for the development of ECs and is also required for the formation of functional vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a potential strategy for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 as a therapeutic tool may be applicable to the treatment of a variety of vascular disorders. This study provides a better understanding of the development of ECs and may lead to the development of a new therapeutic strategy for vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are implicated in cancer and autoimmune diseases. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of these genes, augmentor-α1, augmentor-α2, and augmentor-β, are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor that is present in the skin and the eye of adult zebrafish. We also demonstrate that augmentor-α2 and augmentor-β are essential for the development of iridophores in the eye. These results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insight into the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands in the development of a vertebrate. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the treatment of T2D is still a challenge. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Indeed, Pax6 messenger RNA and protein levels were down-regulated and its nuclear localization was lost in STING-βKO β-cells. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. Using silent trans-complementary mutants, we then demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Competition experiments indicated that this interaction favored copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of the complex interplay of multiple factors. However, the focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that were extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examined geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the coterminous United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. During the 21-y time period, the human-caused fire season was three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season and added an average of 40,000 wildfires per year across the United States. Human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of these complications are not fully understood. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Finally, we show that a drug that inhibits viral replication can be effective in reducing the peak median plasma viral load. However, the timing of the treatment is critical. Treatment given too late is mostly ineffective. Treatment given too early can lead to a rebound of the viral load. These results can help guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a key consequence of this breakdown, leading to the death of the coral host. We show that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress is a key driver of this process. This process is driven by the energy demand of the coral host, which is increased by the heat stress. The resulting shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system and microbiota. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiota and the activity of the immune system, leading to a regenerative response and tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting the activity of the immune system or the microbiome can restore the barrier function of the epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis and organismal lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the immune system and the microbiome to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides a potential mechanism for the development of cancer-promoting bacteria and a strategy for cancer prevention. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond well to chemotherapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a unique, ∼192-y series of volcanic eruptions, which plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and subsequently to a rapid advance of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the implications of fishing for biodiversity, food security, and sustainability. We find that river fisheries are concentrated in regions with high human population density and low biodiversity, and that fishing is most intense in rivers with the highest levels of degradation. Our data highlight the importance of inland fisheries for food security, particularly in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce. At the same time, our results suggest that fishing in regions of high biodiversity may be unsustainable, and that conservation efforts should be prioritized in these areas. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective policies to protect freshwater biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by reducing neuronal activity and elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a useful platform for discovering genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, this study suggests that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more capable of regeneration than previously appreciated. This study also suggests that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more capable of regeneration than previously appreciated.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity in all organisms. In plants, recombination is thought to be more uniform than in animals, with recombination occurring at a constant rate throughout the genome. However, this assumption has not been tested. Here, we present a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We show that recombination is not uniform across the genome, but rather is highly variable, with some regions of the genome showing no detectable recombination. This variation is likely to have a major impact on the evolution of plants.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity that are used to identify and localize brain areas. However, the brain is also a metabolic system, with fluctuations in total activity that are not reflected in functional connectivity. We used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting organization of the brain, and to assess its functional role. We found that the dominant resting metabolic network in healthy subjects was topologically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. Network deactivation was reduced in early Parkinson’s disease, and partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes raises the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. (Read more)

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. In this study, we show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years in people with diabetes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The etiology of this disease is complex and involves multiple factors, including the composition of the gut microbiota. The aim of the present study was to explore whether changes in gut permeability are linked to gut-microbiota composition and activity in alcohol-dependent subjects. We also investigated whether gut dysfunction is associated with the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Finally, we tested the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence, which may be important psychological factors of relapse. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the composition of its volatile chemical profile. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is largely unknown, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall aroma of tomato fruit is poorly understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato aroma. It also opens the door to the development of tomato varieties with improved flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of conservation strategies and the management of ecosystems under global warming.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains two subregions, the MEC proper and the parasubiculum, which are anatomically and functionally distinct. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to examine the organization of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for the formation of a spatial map, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings suggest that the organization of MEC and parasubiculum is more complex than previously thought. They also provide a framework for future studies of the function of these two regions. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by loss of movement control and motivation, and the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that the dopamine-producing cells are connected to other brain regions by a system of specialized neuronal formations. These formations, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are likely critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we feel connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for heart rate control and are the only cardiac cells that have the ability to generate action potentials. SAN function is regulated by a complex network of ion channels and stores of intracellular Ca2+ (Ca2+ stores). Stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ stores and is also expressed in SANCs. Here, we report that STIM1 is a key regulator of Ca2+ stores in SANCs and is involved in the regulation of SAN function. Our findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which STIM1 regulates Ca2+ stores in SANCs and contributes to SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has been controversial. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, in wild-type rice but not in rice plants with RNAi lines of allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1), which are key enzymes in jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception, respectively. This interaction between Si and JA was associated with increased Si accumulation and JA accumulation, as well as with enhanced defense responses, including higher levels of JA, defense marker gene expression, and protease inhibitor activity. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in rice defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well known. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine, and they are also the most important source of biomolecules for drug discovery. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. (Show more)

The world’s largest lakes are often the most valuable and threatened ecosystems in their regions. Lake Michigan is no exception. The lake is home to a diverse array of fish and wildlife, and its nearshore ecosystems support a thriving recreational and commercial fishery. However, the lake is also threatened by eutrophication, which is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. We show that small tributaries of Lake Michigan deliver a disproportionate amount of the nutrients that fuel coastal algal blooms. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in these areas could have a large impact on the health of the lake.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is made available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. This work may help to develop new therapies for this devastating disease. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with an injection of organic matter into the ocean, which led to anoxia and a biodiversity nadir. Our results highlight the importance of organic matter in the Earth system and the role of climate change in the evolution of life.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the primary certification body for palm oil, and its certification is often required by major corporations and governments. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33% from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations, but also the need for certification to be more effective in reducing deforestation in peatlands and fire. This is particularly important given the growing demand for palm oil.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of its fitness. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce multiple genotypic sexes. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has four possible genotypes for sex determination, which produce four possible phenotypes. We show that the modularity of these four phenotypes results from the interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by both vitamin A and iron. Vitamin A is a potent prooxidant that is photodegraded into reactive intermediates that can damage the retina. Iron is also a prooxidant that is present in the retina and is a cofactor for the photodegradation of vitamin A. We show that iron levels in the retina impact the levels of a class of molecules that are important for the health of the retina. This work has implications for the retina and for the rest of the body, given that iron is a cofactor for many reactions that are important for health. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization, but the mechanisms behind this process are still unclear. Here we show that siphonophore specialization is not a dead end, but rather a process that can be reversed. We also show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles is strongly linked to prey type, and that this association is associated with the evolution of the nematocysts. Our findings contribute to understanding the mechanisms behind the evolution of specialization, and how it has shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is limited, and the oldest known hominin hand fossils are incomplete. This study provides the earliest known evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. In this study, we identify a metabolic pathway that is critical for cancer cell growth. We show that this pathway is a targetable metabolic vulnerability of cancer.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study has important implications for policy makers, as forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for a more holistic approach to food and nutrition security, which considers the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
